page.title: 01Charney Bassett,Lyford,farms
page.content: Being in the Vale of the White Horse, the land is very flat. Farms are the dominant feature of the landscape. They average 200 acres in size, and are primarily engaged in dairy farming and crop-growing. There are only two residential areas : the village of Charney Bassett and the smaller hamlet Lyford. The River Ock flows in a north- easterly direction, and after being joined by Land Brook and Childrey Brook meets the River Thames at Abingdon. Historic buildings include manor houses and almshouses. The most interesting is Charney Manor which is owned by Quakers and used as a retreat & conference centre. Modern life in the area contains few amenities, but Charney Bassett has an active and varied social life. Public transport has decreased gradually over the years , and there are few buses.
